'''Enoki''' (''Flammulina velutipes'') is a [[mushroom]] that is well-known for its role in [[Japanese cuisine]], where it is also known as '''Enokitake'''(榎茸, エノキタケ, {{IPA-ja|enokitake}}).<ref>{{cite web|title=enokitake|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/enokitake|work=Dictionary.com|publisher=Dictionary.com, LLC|accessdate=14 May 2012|author=Dictionary.com|year=2012}}</ref>

Commercially-farmed enoki is a long, thin white mushroom and is a popular ingredient for soups, especially in [[East Asian cuisine]], but can be used for [[Salad|salads]] and other dishes. The mushroom has a crisp texture and can be [[Refrigeration|refrigerated]] for approximately one week. The farmed form is also known as '''golden needle mushroom''', '''futu mushroom''' or '''lily mushroom'''.
The farmed ''F. velutipes'' is sold both fresh or canned.

The wild forms differ in color, texture, and sliminess and may be called '''futu''', '''seafood mushrooms''', '''winter mushrooms''' or '''winter fungus''', '''velvet foot''', '''velvet stem''' or '''velvet shank'''.<ref>[http://zxmxuerong.en.ec21.com/Seafood_Mushroom--7946177_7946376.html Shanghai Xuerong Biotechnology Co Ltd on Seafood Mushrooms]</ref> 

When picking it in the wild, it is important not to confuse it with the poisonous ''[[Galerina marginata]]''. ''Flammulina velutipes'' can be distinguished by its shiny and sticky caps, white spores, and the absence of a ring on the stem. ''Galerina marginata'' presents brown caps and stipe and most notably has brown, rusty spores. It also tends to grow isolated and it presents a ring.

==Features==
The mushroom naturally grows on the [[Tree stump|stumps]] of the Chinese hackberry tree (''[[Celtis sinensis]]'', "enoki" in Japanese) and on other trees, such as [[ash (tree)|ash]], [[mulberry]] and [[persimmon]] trees.

There is a significant difference in appearance between the [[Wildlife|wild]] and [[Fungiculture|cultivated]] types of the mushroom. Cultivated mushrooms have not been exposed to light, resulting in a white color, whereas wild mushrooms usually display a dark brown color. Cultivated mushrooms are grown in a [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>)-rich environment to nurture the development of long thin stems, whereas wild mushrooms produce a much shorter and thicker stem.

The wild variety of the mushroom may be found from September through to March, hence the name winter fungus.

==Names==
{{mycomorphbox
| name = Flammulina velutipes
| whichGills = adnexed
| capShape = convex
| hymeniumType=gills
| stipeCharacter=bare
| ecologicalType=saprotrophic
| sporePrintColor=white
| howEdible=choice}}
The names ''enokitake'' ([[:ja:榎茸|榎茸]]、[[:ja:エノキタケ|エノキタケ]]), ''enokidake'' ([[:ja:榎茸|榎茸]]、[[:ja:エノキダケ|エノキダケ]]) and ''enoki'' ([[:ja:榎|榎]]、[[:ja:エノキ|エノキ]]) are derived from the [[Japanese language]]. In Mandarin [[Chinese language|Chinese]], the mushroom is called  {{lang|zh-hans|{{linktext|金針菇}}}} (''{{linktext|jīnzhēngū}}'', "gold needle mushroom") or [[wiktionary:金|金]][[wiktionary:菇|菇]] (''jīngū'', "gold mushroom"). In [[India]] it is called [http://www.chhattisgarhrecipes.com/2017/01/futu-long-mushroom.html?m=1 ''futu''], [[Korean language|in Korean]], it is called ''paengi beoseot'' (팽이버섯) which means "mushroom planted near catalpa", and ''nấm kim châm'' in [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]]. In [[Hungary]] it is called ''[[:hu:T%C3%A9li f%C3%BCl%C5%91ke|téli fülőke]]'', meaning "winter ear".

==Health properties==

Enokitake mushrooms contain [[antioxidants]],<ref name="pmid = 19323731">{{cite journal |vauthors=Bao HN, Ushio H, Ohshima T |title=Antioxidative activities of mushroom (''Flammulina velutipes'') extract added to bigeye tuna meat: dose-dependent efficacy and comparison with other biological antioxidants |journal=Journal of Food Science |volume=74 |issue=2 |pages=C162–9 |date=March 2009 |pmid=19323731 |doi=10.1111/j.1750-3841.2009.01069.x}}</ref><ref name="pmid = 18841979 ">{{cite journal |vauthors=Bao HN, Ushio H, Ohshima T |title=Antioxidative activity and antidiscoloration efficacy of ergothioneine in mushroom (''Flammulina velutipes'') extract added to beef and fish meats |journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry |volume=56 |issue=21 |pages=10032–40 |date=November 2008 |pmid=18841979 |doi=10.1021/jf8017063}}</ref> like [[ergothioneine]].<ref name="pmid = 18841979 "/> [[Animal testing]] has indicated possible applications in the development of [[vaccine]]s and [[cancer immunotherapy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=New look at two wonder mushrooms|url=http://www.nus.edu.sg/research/rg27.php |publisher=National University of Singapore |accessdate=14 May 2012 |year=2001–2012}}</ref>

Research at the [[National University of Singapore]], first published in 2005,<!-- see talk page --> stated that the stalk of the golden needle mushroom contains a large quantity of a [[protein]], named "Five"/"FIP-fve" by the researchers, that helps in the regulation of the [[immune system]]. The mushroom also contains [[Flammutoxin]], a [[Cytolysis|cytolytic]] and [[Cardiotoxicity|cardiotoxic]] protein<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tomita T, Ishikawa D, Noguchi T, Katayama E, Hashimoto Y |title=Assembly of flammutoxin, a cytolytic protein from the edible mushroom ''Flammulina velutipes'', into a pore-forming ring-shaped oligomer on the target cell |journal=The Biochemical Journal |volume=333 |issue=1 |pages=129–37 |date=July 1998 |pmid=9639572 |pmc=1219565 |url=http://www.biochemj.org/bj/333/0129/bj3330129.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Lin |first=JY |last2=Wu |first2=HL |last3=Shi |first3=GY |title=Toxicity of the cardiotoxic protein flammutoxin, isolate from edible mushroom ''Flammulina velutipes'' |journal=Toxicon |volume=13 |issue=5 |pages=323–31 |date=November 1975 |pmid=54950 |doi=10.1016/0041-0101(75)90191-9}}</ref> that has proven to be non-toxic when absorbed/taken orally.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tomita |first=Toshio |author2=Dai Ishikawa |author3=Takayasu Noguchi |author4=Eisaku Katayama |author5=Yohichi Hashimoto |title=Assembly of flammutoxin, a cytolytic protein from the edible mushroom ''Flammulina velutipes'', into a pore-forming ring-shaped oligomer on the target cell |journal=Biochemical Journal |date=8 April 1998 |issue=333 |pages=129–137 |url=http://www.biochemj.org/bj/333/0129/bj3330129.htm|pmc=1219565 }}</ref>
